newsitem.title: UK: LME gets off to slow start, trade lethargic.
newsitem.headline: LME gets off to slow start, trade lethargic.

text.p: Activity was subdued during early Tuesday LME trading, with prices largely clinging to levels set late on Monday.
Traders saw little to suggest the market would be shaken out of its torpor in the short term, and said prices were just drifting gently lower.
"It is summer, and there is a lot of lethargy around," one said.
Copper fluctuated in a $2,375/2,380 a tonne band, which was down from Monday's $2,399 kerb close but little different from the prices prevailing during late inter-office trading in the evening.
"The market has held up fairly well, considering the (2,250-tonne) stock rise," the trader said.
But copper looked to be coming under pressure, with chart targets of $2,355 beckoning if current levels around $2,375 were lost.
Spreads were also softening in the run-up to the late July tight dates, with some lending seen throughout Monday. Cash/threes was around a $135 backwardation, some $15 softer than pre-weekend levels.
Elsewhere, aluminium sagged from initial steady levels to $1,579, down $8 from Monday. Another stock fall -- 3,150 tonnes -- passed by without any impact.
"Stocks are down all the time now -- the surprise will be when they come in one day up," another trader said.

Zinc dipped back under $1,450 at one point, but was largely supported around that level and was just $4 easier at $1,452. In the short term, further consolidation below the recent $1,495 high seemed likely.
Nickel was trading routinely just under Monday's closing levels, with three months $60 softer at $6,800.
Tin and lead were indicated at softer levels of $5,520/40 and $651/653 respectively. Alloy was quoted at $1,435/40.
